question: In ISO 42001, what is the main purpose of an Artificial Intelligence Management System (AIMS)?
answer: To systematically plan, operate, monitor, and improve AI systems so they are controlled, responsible, and aligned with organizational objectives.
options: To replace all existing management systems with a single AI platform.
To provide a catalog of technical algorithms an organization must implement.
To systematically plan, operate, monitor, and improve AI systems so they are controlled, responsible, and aligned with organizational objectives.
To guarantee that all AI systems will be free of errors.

question: Which kinds of activities are typically covered by the scope of an AIMS under ISO 42001?
answer: Activities related to the lifecycle of AI systems, such as planning, development, operation, monitoring, and decommissioning.
options: Only the procurement of cloud services for AI workloads.
Activities related to the lifecycle of AI systems, such as planning, development, operation, monitoring, and decommissioning.
Only model training and hyperparameter tuning.
Only the legal review of AI contracts.

question: Who is ultimately responsible for the AIMS within an organization following ISO 42001?
answer: Top management, who must ensure the AIMS is established, resourced, and integrated into business processes.
options: Only external consultants hired to implement AI projects.
An individual data scientist working on a single model.
Top management, who must ensure the AIMS is established, resourced, and integrated into business processes.
Only the IT operations team running the infrastructure.

question: How does ISO 42001 relate to other management system standards such as ISO 27001 or ISO 9001?
answer: It is designed to be compatible with other management system standards so organizations can integrate the AIMS with existing frameworks.
options: It replaces all other management system standards and makes them obsolete.
It is unrelated to other management system standards and cannot be integrated.
It is designed to be compatible with other management system standards so organizations can integrate the AIMS with existing frameworks.
It only applies to organizations that do not use any other standards.

question: Why is it important to clearly define the scope of the AIMS in ISO 42001?
answer: A clear scope ensures everyone understands which AI systems, processes, and locations are controlled by the AIMS, avoiding gaps or unrealistic expectations.
options: Because scope statements are required only for marketing purposes.
To avoid the need for documenting any supporting processes.
A clear scope ensures everyone understands which AI systems, processes, and locations are controlled by the AIMS, avoiding gaps or unrealistic expectations.
So that individual teams can interpret the AIMS requirements in any way they prefer.

question: How does an AIMS help align AI initiatives with organizational objectives?
answer: By requiring objectives, roles, and processes so AI activities support business goals, risk appetite, and responsible AI principles.
options: By allowing each AI team to set its own objectives independently of business strategy.
By focusing solely on technical model accuracy, ignoring business impact.
By requiring objectives, roles, and processes so AI activities support business goals, risk appetite, and responsible AI principles.
By limiting AI to experimental prototypes only.

question: What is one benefit of implementing an AIMS as a formal management system rather than handling AI risks informally?
answer: A formal AIMS provides structured processes, responsibilities, and continual improvement, reducing reliance on ad-hoc decisions.
options: It removes the need to involve top management in AI decisions.
A formal AIMS provides structured processes, responsibilities, and continual improvement, reducing reliance on ad-hoc decisions.
It guarantees AI products will always be delivered faster than competitors.
It eliminates the need to consult affected stakeholders.

question: An organization operates several AI-enabled services but has never defined which ones fall under its AIMS. What is the most appropriate first step?
answer: Identify all relevant AI systems and define the AIMS scope so it is clear which systems and activities are covered.
options: Immediately start decommissioning any AI system that looks risky.
Wait for an external auditor to decide which AI systems are in scope.
Identify all relevant AI systems and define the AIMS scope so it is clear which systems and activities are covered.
Leave the scope undefined so teams can apply AIMS controls as they see fit.

question: A product team wants to launch a new AI feature quickly and argues that the AIMS will slow them down. What is the best response aligned with ISO 42001?
answer: Explain that the AIMS is intended to integrate AI work with business objectives and risk management, and that controls should be scaled but not bypassed.
options: Agree to exclude the new feature from the AIMS so it can launch faster.
Suspend the AIMS for all products until the feature is released.
Explain that the AIMS is intended to integrate AI work with business objectives and risk management, and that controls should be scaled but not bypassed.
Require the team to stop all AI work permanently.

question: Top management has approved an AI strategy but has not allocated resources or assigned roles for the AIMS. What should be done to align with ISO 42001?
answer: Ensure top management assigns responsibilities and resources so the AIMS can be established, implemented, and maintained effectively.
options: Proceed with the AIMS implementation without defined roles or resources.
Wait for external regulators to assign roles for the organization.
Ensure top management assigns responsibilities and resources so the AIMS can be established, implemented, and maintained effectively.
Limit the AIMS to a single pilot project and ignore the rest of the organization.
